CBS Boston reported on April 29, 2013, about a guy who lost his entire life savings on a carnival game. 🎡 

Daniel Kahneman, Jack L. Knetsch, and Richard H. Thaler discussed concepts like the Endowment Effect, Loss Aversion, and Status Quo Bias in their paper, “Anomalies: The Endowment Effect, Loss Aversion, and Status Quo Bias,” published in the Journal of Economic Perspective (1991). 

Tom Stafford wrote an article titled “Why We Love to Hoard… and How You Can Overcome It” for BBC News on July 17, 2012, exploring our tendency to collect stuff. 

I first shared these ideas in a blog post for the Harvard Business Review called “The Disciplined Pursuit of Less” on August 8, 2012. 

Hal R. Arkes and Peter Aykon examined the Sunk Cost and Concorde Effects in their paper, “The Sunk Cost and Concorde Effects: Are Humans Less Rational Than Lower Animals?” published in the Psychological Bulletin (1999). 

James Surowiecki wrote about the “Sunk-Cost Feeling” in The New Yorker on January 21, 2013, highlighting how we often cling to past investments. 

Daniel Shapero shared insights on LinkedIn in his article “Great Managers Prune as Well as Plant” on December 13, 2012, emphasizing the importance of letting go. 

Mark Harris wrote in the New York Times on January 6, 2008, that in 1980, the film Ordinary People won Best Picture, but its editor, Jeff Kanew, wasn’t nominated for Best Editing. 

Harris also discussed the topic further in “Which Editing.” 

Lastly, check out the video “Jack Dorsey: The CEO as Chief Editor,” uploaded to YouTube on February 15, 2011.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The text references various sources discussing concepts related to decision-making, biases, and the importance of prioritization in life and work.
